description: From Middle English souple, from Old French souple, soupple (“soft, lithe, yielding”), from Latin supplic-, supplex (“suppliant, submissive, kneeling”), of uncertain formation. Either from sub + plicō (“bend”) (compare complex), or from sub + plācō (“placate”). More at sub-, placate.

entries.meaning: Lithe and agile when moving and bending.
(figuratively) Compliant; yielding to the will of others.

verbs.description: supple (third-person singular simple present supples, present participle suppling, simple past and past participle suppled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make or become supple.
(transitive) To make compliant, submissive, or obedient.
examples: They should supple our stiff wilfulness.
